html:
My review of Evernote TOS:

Looks like Evernote - http://evernote.com/legal/tos.php - has decent TOS.  I’d give them a green light.

-They do their best not to look at what you upload.  No data mining.
-Other than IP issues, all disputes are restricted binding arbitration, and there’s a no-class-action clause.  Don’t know if it’s enforceable, but it’s there.
-They don’t take responsibility for third-party services.  No big surprise.

Privacy page - http://evernote.com/legal/privacy.php

-Information pulled from your computer includes email and account name (as entered to make an account), your IP address (to localize), hardware and software.  
-There’s a whole page on cookies - http://evernote.com/legal/cookies.php - which describes their use of cookies for their own functional purposes, marketing, and some social media interaction (facebook, google+, etc….)

-Includes very straightforward paragraph re: looking at your notes:

Does Evernote Review My Notes?

As a rule, Evernote employees do not monitor or view your personal information or Content stored in the Service, but it may be viewed if we believe our Terms of Service have been violated and confirmation is required, if we need to do so in order to respond to your requests for user support, or we otherwise determine that we have an obligation to review it as described in our Terms of Service. Your Notes also may be viewed where necessary to protect the rights, property or personal safety of Evernote and its users, or in order to comply with our legal obligations, such as responding to warrants, court orders or other legal process.


-Clear listing on http://evernote.com/privacy/data_usage.php of how the software accesses data on various devices, and why.

-Also, a nice page on how to remove your account here http://evernote.com/contact/support/kb/#/article/23403793


--
tosdr.org | twitter.com/tosdr | github.com/tosdr
---

subject: Evernote TOS
text:
My review of Evernote TOS:

Looks like Evernote - http://evernote.com/legal/tos.php - has decent TOS.  I’d give them a green light.

-They do their best not to look at what you upload.  No data mining.
-Other than IP issues, all disputes are restricted binding arbitration, and there’s a no-class-action clause.  Don’t know if it’s enforceable, but it’s there.
-They don’t take responsibility for third-party services.  No big surprise.

Privacy page - http://evernote.com/legal/privacy.php

-Information pulled from your computer includes email and account name (as entered to make an account), your IP address (to localize), hardware and software.  
-There’s a whole page on cookies - http://evernote.com/legal/cookies.php - which describes their use of cookies for their own functional purposes, marketing, and some social media interaction (facebook, google+, etc….)

-Includes very straightforward paragraph re: looking at your notes:
Does Evernote Review My Notes?
As a rule, Evernote employees do not monitor or view your personal information or Content stored in the Service, but it may be viewed if we believe our Terms of Service have been violated and confirmation is required, if we need to do so in order to respond to your requests for user support, or we otherwise determine that we have an obligation to review it as described in our Terms of Service. Your Notes also may be viewed where necessary to protect the rights, property or personal safety of Evernote and its users, or in order to comply with our legal obligations, such as responding to warrants, court orders or other legal process.


-Clear listing on http://evernote.com/privacy/data_usage.php of how the software accesses data on various devices, and why.

-Also, a nice page on how to remove your account here http://evernote.com/contact/support/kb/#/article/23403793
